transcription.text: [ Music ]
All right, for those of you who are just walking back
into the room, we're switching it back up to the opportunity
and global impact track.
Next up, we will hear from Mario Havel,
and he will be sharing what he has learned
from building a parallel economy using Ethereum.
Before I introduce Mario, do we have friends
in the audience from Central Europe today?
Raise your hand, Central Europe.
Cool, cool, cool.
Okay, Mario is someone I've had the great pleasure
of hanging out with and also learning from.
He is a protocol supporter and researcher working
with the Ethereum Foundation, co-founder
of the Bordeaux Hackerspace, a bit louder.
[ Applause ]
>> Mario has been building and educating local communities
in Bratislava, Prague, Barcelona, inspired many people
to live crypto-native and contribute to the free
and open source software ecosystems.
Please join me in welcoming Mario.
[ Applause ]
>> Thank you very much.
Thank you so much for the lovely introduction.
I really appreciate that.
And I'm excited to hear so many friends
from Central Europe here,
because so what I'm planning to do here today is actually
to share a bit of experience
from Central Europe, experience of building local parallel
policy. So the name of the talk in the schedule is building
parallel economy, but that's two narrow topic
and it will be actually more about parallel society,
parallel structures in general.
So yeah, so that's the first question I guess.
What is this parallel society?
What are these parallel structures I'm talking about?
And yeah, let's see where it leads.
So first of all, to somehow define,
to explain what are the parallel societies,
let's talk a bit about theory of social change.
I believe that many people in the world,
but especially all of you folks here have ideas how
to make world better, how to improve societies,
how to make betterment for everybody,
because well, there are many issues in the current society,
in the governments, in the cultures,
and there are a bunch of utopias,
but especially there are various ways how to achieve the change,
how to achieve this improvement.
And I will very oversimplify the social change story.
I'm very sorry about that.
But to sum it up, we have some top down approach
to changing society, which is we can imagine some politician
creating better rules which will improve the life.
We have, or like also, I vote, right?
I'm giving my voice to somebody speaking for me.
So he has then the top down power.
The bottom up approach coming from communities,
coming from people, from activists,
whether it's intrapreneural, non-profit activism,
and people actually building projects
which are permissionlessly changing the world.
And within the social change,
I also have to mention revolutions,
which are another, maybe kind of sudden,
kind of change in society.
I hope you can see the slides through me, actually.
Yeah, nice.
And we can argue about many issues of these approaches.
First of all, there is the violence involved,
especially in the top down approach.
When we have government enforcing rules,
it requires coercion.
Also, revolution can be kind of violent.
And there might be hidden violence,
even in some bottom up approaches.
So that's one of the critique.
And the second thing is effectiveness of various approaches
to social change.
And the effectiveness in the terms of social context, I would say.
So the problem with, for example,
the top down approach is that the politician
or somebody who is creating these rules for us
needs to follow the side-guides of society,
the side-guides of society, the social context.
For example, the politician in very conservative country
cannot make very liberal reforms, right?
So he always needs to follow what the electorate wants.
But also in the bottom up systems,
we are limited by the social context in multiple ways.
Like when I'm, when you are creating a movement,
which is too outside of the overturned window,
it's hard to get interaction.
And you might be even out-sensored.
And also in the activism we see,
we see these limits where I'm putting my productive energy
to something I believe in,
but it might be used completely differently
in the current social context.
So for example, I'm building some open source tools.
I'm contributing to some open source ecosystem.
And now government takes this,
takes this open program and uses it for an army.
For example, I'm actually contributed to something
I didn't want it at all.
So yeah, so we can argue about like effectiveness
and issues with the social change.
But the main issue here, or what I want to mention,
is that none of these work in totalitarian regimes.
So in the, in the authoritarian regime where you,
well, cannot really vote, so the top-down doesn't work at all.
You don't have freedom of expression,
you people cannot, cannot do any first-effectivism.
This is, this is not possible.
And so what I like to share here is the experience
from Czechoslovakia, which experienced decades of totalitarian
terrorism after communist regime,
which started after Second World War.
And in late '60s, there was a kind of a liberal wave
in the socialist communist run, Czechoslovakia,
which argued for opening borders
so people can actually travel to the west, for example.
Ergud for certain free market principles and so on and so on.
And of course, the big Soviet brother didn't like that.
And as a part of the Eastern Bloc, it was something
which was very discouraged, and it resulted in
invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968.
And yeah, so the version of the Soviet is just sent thanks.
And well, compared to Ukraine, these days,
Czechoslovakia wasn't able to fight back.
So for coming years, it experienced strong Soviet-run
communist totalitarian regime.
And especially in the '70s, in the coming years,
there was an era of so-called normalization,
which was a wave of a strong totalitarianism.
And this resulted in intellectuals, in people,
in scientists, in artists being persecuted,
being forced to become just workforce,
not the intellectuals, and people were persecuted,
spied on.
And of course, this kind of totalitarianism results
in some opposition, in some distant movement.
And there was, so around the whole Eastern Bloc,
there were many interesting and courageous distant movements.
And in Czechoslovakia, there was also various of them,
for example, like second culture, which was, for example,
folk singers, artists, like--
but one important and probably the best renowned
distant movement from Czech Republic or Czechoslovakia,
that I need to mention, is Charter 77.
And Charter 77 was--
well, it was a collection of essays.
It was petition, which was appealing to government,
so it started to comply with basically what it promised,
with-- to stop violating human rights, civic rights.
And it's peaceful as humanitarian.
This movement was-- the government really took it back.
The government started to chase people behind Charter 77,
and publicly destroyed their figures.
And basically, it was-- yeah, so there are many interesting people
in this picture who might know, on the very left,
Vázlov Havel, who later became the first president
of Czech Republic, and his world renowned humanitarian,
liberal.
And so the Charter, it was a collection of essays.
It has had few spokesman.
And one of the colleagues of Vázlov had one of the leading
personas in Charter 77 on the right here was Vázlov Benda.
And he, within this movement, he actually focused on exploring
how is the movement itself evolving, how it's-- how it reacts
to the persecution from government.
And he described it as Peral Polis.
He noticed that this contraculture dispersecuted subculture
or movement is building Peral structures, its own culture,
its own education.
There was many books which were just prohibited,
and these were distributed, you know, hand-reverenton
within these communities.
So he described it as Peral Polis.
And Peral Knee Polis in original or Peral Polis could be defined
as set of strategies for creating some independent society.
This is outside of the context, this big quote here by Erb Eiffeler,
but it kind of sums up the idea that I have there.
Basically, let's-- when I'm in the society,
like the communist regime, right, I cannot fight against it.
We cannot have protests because we will be violently punished.
We don't have any freedom of expression.
We cannot write freely.
We cannot-- there is only single party, the communist party,
we can vote, we cannot change anything.
So we are forced to building free independent Peral structures.
And it's also-- it's not just, like, out of necessity,
but I believe that it's also effective and moral approach.
This is something similar to what Gandhi says, right,
be the change you want to see in the world.
And so, yeah, Peral Polis is, to me, set of strategies, set of various Peral structures.
And here are some examples.
So the pillars of Peral Polis would be not just--
the name of the talk is the Peral Academy,
but here it's just within the context, right?
So it's Peral Education, Peral Academy, Peral Cal--
Cal-- Peral-- Cal-- Culture.
So we correct this protection, which was actually the main reason
behind the Charter 77 Peral infrastructure,
governance systems for these people.
And this is not something which is strictly defined, which is, like, okay,
this is the Peral Polis, these structures.
It's-- these are just examples.
It's always based on the circumstances, what the independence of society
actually requires in that moment.
And it's-- it's completely up to you, right,
of the community, what it needs in that context.
And, yeah, speaking about the social context, when I mentioned before,
so here is a beautiful thing which Peral Polis enables,
and that's actually having these, let's say,
principles rooted in the Peral Polis itself.
So when we are building these Peral structures,
we are building them on the basis of positive social context,
and we can feel free to put our-- our protective energy towards Peral Polis.
Czechoslovak dissidents invented-- it's something that was also been described,
but I would say it's anthropological constant throughout the history.
We see people creating Peral structures out of necessity throughout the whole history,
whether it's Christians who were persecuted in the ancient Rome,
or in the recent history, maybe hippie movement or LGBT and similar contour cultures,
ended up actually building their own Peral structures.
Okay, now we're Ethereum fits in all of this,
and Ethereum, or like speaking about these technologies,
I have to go all the way back to Sefirpunk,
and Sefirpunk is another movement which actually comes to life in late '70s and '80s,
and this was a movement community of various interesting people,
many programmers, scientists, mathematicians, entrepreneurs,
people who at a time were internet computers and encryptions that were to spread,
the governments-- well, wanted to fight with it, right?
The government said the encryption is a weapon.
It's something which only army can have,
and wanted to limit what people can do with their computers,
what can actually happen, what kind of encryption we can use,
and Sefirpunk's were people who stood against this,
who not just built tools, as it's described here, really nicely, like Eric Hughes.
It's built the tools, but also created presidencies against regulation of cryptography,
for example, Filmor, who started EFF, Electronic Frontier Foundation,
very renowned in today, and so the Sefirpunk's.
So the first part here, it's part of a Sefirpunk manifesto by Eric Hughes,
and the second part is the Manifesto of Krypton Arkey,
which is a movement coming out from the-- growing from the Sefirpunk,
and the manifesto was written by Timoty C. May, the left in the picture,
and Timoty May took the idea of the Sefirpunk even further,
not just to protect ourselves, but to actually achieve freedom through the digital technologies.
It's like 30 years old, it was very distributed on a conference,
Krip 2.88 in 1988, and I have to say it's very prophetic if you read it,
and he's arguing basically about what we see today.
I believe that today, when you look at the world,
when you look at the digital world, digital or real, is,
well, I would say bigger than the physical one, it's maybe even more important,
and we can leverage these technologies because the government,
the authorians, will have the power, the coercion power in the physical world,
but they are losing it and maybe never really had it in the digital one.
And that's thanks to Tools of Krypton Arkey.
The Krypton Arkey is a bit like something ideological,
like it's some political idea, like anarchism based on Krypton, I don't know.
To me, Krypton Arkeyism is a set of tools.
It's a toolbox which allows for many important things.
Generally, I would say that Krypton Arkey allows to build human interactions
more voluntarily than based on coercion,
and it comes with many important tools,
with tools for anonymity on the Internet, digital money,
encryption and privacy, which I believe is the fundamental building for freedom.
So we have this parallel polis, which is set of strategies for building independent parallel structures,
and now we have Krypton Arkey, which is set of tools for building independent communities.
Well, it kind of fits together, doesn't it?
So there is this level of building in Prague called "Parel
and the Polis", as you can see, instead of Krypton Arkey.
And I would say that this building is actually like the manifestation of the connection between the physical and digital world.
And the overall structures, this independent communities thanks to the tools of Krypton Arkey.
And Parel and the Polis has been running for over nine years now,
educating about these technologies and experimenting with them.
And so in the talk, I would like to actually later explain some examples of how we experimented with Ethereum
as a tool of Krypton Arkey for building Parel societies.
But one piece that got Parel and Polis famous is actually this little place, Bordele.
And many of you who followed the merge might heard about Bordele WTF,
but it's named after actual physical place, which is in basement down there of this building.
And the basement is called Bordele, and you might know these memes about the Robston merge with the whole "Get Team" which happened there.
So the Parel and Polis is like open platform.
Talking about a specific project, it's open platform for various communities to meet.
Because like when various communities, now I'm talking about the crypto, not just Ethereum,
but we have Bitcoiners, Monera people, I have Monera socks here.
And also people who are actually building privacy tooling and encryption tooling and artists and so on,
meet in this place and create beautiful things.
So there are a few things we experimented with in Parel, Polis considering Ethereum.
So like, I mean, I don't really have to explain this.
I believe that you folks who understand Ethereum know that it's such a strong tool for what I explained
because it enables permissionless coordination.
And I would say it's a cypherpunk, solarpunk, lunarpunk, sagepunk, and pixelpunk tool.
A very versatile tool.
When I have a toolbox of the crypto-archy tools, Ethereum would be a Swiss knife,
which enables me many things.
And these are some of those few important things that we use in our little experiment with Parel, Polis.
And first of all, the DeFi or the open finance, the permissionless finance, which Ethereum enables.
Is this something which is necessary for, well, I would say, dissidents or for people who don't have access to the traditional finance
or don't agree with the morality of the traditional finance and want to explore the permissionless alternatives.
And Parel, Polis, this building I showed, accepts only cryptocurrencies for the whole of its existence.
There is actually a Bitcoin cafe, it's a place where it's cafe which accepts only crypto.
There is a co-working, there is many people coming to this building and they are forced to pay with crypto.
So all the income is actually only cryptocurrencies.
And it's kind of a mess to live crypto natively because of the volatility, because of the bear markets, which will come always, right?
So thanks to Ethereum, we have tools like stablecoins, we have tools like collateralized loans.
So the DeFi here is not about chasing yield farming, but about actually using this to survive economically in some parallel economy.
So as an individual who is living without banks, it's a tool which is a necessity to be able to survive with just crypto.
But also as the organization is Polis, it's great we have the tool like loans.
And it's not just using the tools, but there are also people coming from Parel, Polis, who are creating these tools.
There is PWN, pawn finance, which is aiming to bring mortgages for crypto natives, for people who don't have or don't want to have access to the traditional finance.
Public goods, I also don't have to go deep in those because you folks are here, you understand what public goods meme in Ethereum is.
But the realization here, how it clicks, it's really amazing, right?
I mean, we have the whole, the parallel society, the parallel structures, which are mostly all public goods.
The whole building that I show, it's non-profit, it's probably good, which provides education, provides platform.
And it's something which needs to be funded, not via coercion, via taxes or so on, but alternatively, regeneratively.
And would we experience this, that Parel, Polis get successfully, could have funded multiple projects, not just for itself, but for example,
the other tough COVID winter, Parel, Polis took, the volunteers from Parel, Polis had a track with Bitcoin, Caffee on the wheels,
and provided Caffee for doctors fighting the COVID in the hospitals.
And this Caffee was free for them, it was crowdfunded mostly with Bitcoin and fiat, not with Ethereum to be honest,
but still the crowdfunding and the public good finding in Ethereum tools are much stronger.
But Parel, Polis accepts donation on Bitcoin, on Givit, and generally, if we want parallel structures, they need this kind of funding running out of time.
But yeah, the governance, another important part, we need reputation systems and governance.
What we experimented with is for example, tokens for people who are contributing for volunteers who get awarded with our own token.
And based on this, you can track the contributions in the physical space, right?
In the local community, but also in the digital one.
Like example of the digital Parel, Polis would be for example the network states, there is Balaji's book about it,
Vitalik has a good article on it, or like network states, or Parel or cloud societies, or Parel societies, it all sounds same to me.
And these are local or digital communities which need governance and reputation systems, and Ethereum provides that.
Parel, Polis, the specific project in Prague, created these beautiful silver coins or medals,
and the tribute to Alan Turing.
The certificate of these is an FTO in Ethereum, but also before we, there were coins, silver,
and even some gold ones with ironswords, rose woolbreed, and others.
And these had certificate on Bitcoin as a multi-coin Bitcoin, so it was kind of a legacy technology, but still, this is something which sends
crypto weddings were a cool idea, which almost got materialized in the Slovak version of Parel, Polis, and Bratislava,
where a lawyer was working on basically this parallel kind of wedding, where, so as a homosexual,
he was fighting for having simsix marriages, which are not possible in this country, but he created, as a lawyer, he created contracts, peer-to-peer contracts,
which enables similar things as having the normal legal marriage, and the certificate of these can be a contract on Ethereum.
It was, yeah, yeah, security system.
This was a concept which didn't get materialized, but there was a nice idea, a nice concept about having, like, Parel, Uber kind of Polis based on Ethereum.
In a way that I have a fountain, I have a physical device in my home, which I fund through a contract, and when you come, you be pure NFC card, like you have these cards with your ENS,
and you get rewarded by basically securing the perimeter.
As a proof of concept of this, there was a bird feeder in Parel, Polis, that's a cute project, which does this insetivization for this kind of insetivization for feeding birds.
So we have a bird feeder with a device where you tap your card, you put their bird seed, and you get paid from a contract where everybody can send money, right, for feeding the bird.
Incentiv systems, and environmental protection, another important thing which Ethereum also helps with in free independent manner.
There is a project which was also funded thanks to quadratic funding, which was at ETH-PRAC in Parel, Polis, and the F-Tertals.
And these are folks from Envirometeps from Parel, Polis, who, another piece of community which came and learned about this ecosystem.
And these folks are coming to Indonesia, saving turtles, and the thing is that each turtle is unique. They have unique faces, like people.

So they make NFTs under them, and you can adopt them, you can buy them and support the actual protection of the turtles because it's a lot of work to be on the beach all the time and make sure that they are right.
Yeah, good. I think I went through it.
And so the motto that we use in Parel, Polis is "Enter the Outside."
ADI here is that thanks to these technologies, thanks to these Parel structures, we can, I don't want to say opt out.
When people often say this opt out from the system, use crypto, you are opting out, but it's not like opting out to some vacuum because you are actually entering something, right?
So you enter the Parel, Polis, but at the same time you are entering outside. And better in English, I like it in Spanish or Czech, enter Alafwera.
So yeah, enter the outside, I guess that's it. Thank you so much.
(Applause)
I can't believe I made it on time. And I'm sure if we have room for some questions. Anybody?
It's all right. Thank you so much for coming, folks. I really appreciate all of you here. Hope you liked it.
And I will be around here. You can find me. If you see Masked Anon, it's still me. Just leaked it, but whatever.
Yeah, normally I work in the protocol support. This was totally out of EF stuff, but there is my email.
Feel free to contact me or Twitter. Yeah, thank you so much again.
(Applause)
(Silence)
